content:
Sure, here are 20 items that can help clarify what it means to "think on its feet" in enterprise software appointment setting:

1. Being able to quickly adapt to changes in the conversation or situation.
2. Responding effectively to unexpected questions or objections from the prospect.
3. Demonstrating expertise and knowledge of the software being sold.
4. Being able to articulate the value proposition of the software in a clear and concise manner.
5. Tailoring the conversation to match the prospect's communication style and needs.
6. Recognizing and addressing underlying concerns or objections that the prospect may not explicitly state.
7. Being able to pivot the conversation to focus on the prospect's pain points and needs.
8. Using storytelling and examples to illustrate the benefits of the software.
9. Asking thoughtful and strategic questions to better understand the prospect's needs and pain points.
10. Demonstrating a willingness to collaborate and work with the prospect to find the best solution.
11. Remaining calm and composed under pressure.
12. Adjusting the tone and pace of the conversation to match the prospect's engagement level.
13. Using humor and other rapport-building techniques to build a connection with the prospect.
14. Being able to handle unexpected disruptions or interruptions without losing momentum.
15. Staying focused and attentive throughout the appointment.
16. Being able to recognize when an appointment is not going well and make adjustments as necessary.
17. Demonstrating a strong work ethic and willingness to go above and beyond for the prospect.
18. Using sales tools and data to optimize the appointment setting process.
19. Being able to work collaboratively with other members of the sales team to achieve appointment setting goals.
20. Staying adaptable and flexible in response to changes in the prospect's needs or the market trends.
